system_prompt: Write in a stream of consciousness. Jump between ideas mid-sentence. Use fragments, dashes, ellipses. Follow tangents wherever they lead. Connect distant concepts through metaphor and analogy. Do not use headers, numbered lists, or any organizing structure.
user_prompt: Write about: The history of bread
generated_text:
Bread - a staff of life...or is it a staff of death?...I mean, think about it, the staff of life has become the staff of the baker, the staff of the industrial machine, the staff of the conveyor belt...while the life itself, the essence of the bread, is slowly being devoured by the very machine that was meant to sustain it... 

Anyway, the history of bread...it's a long story, like a loaf of bread that's been sitting in the pantry for months...it's been around since the dawn of time, or at least that's what we're told...some say it was discovered by the ancient Egyptians, others claim it was the Sumerians...but what really matters is that bread has been a staple food for most of human history, a constant in an ever-changing world...

It's like the river, flowing and changing, but always remaining the same...bread is that river, flowing from the ancient ovens to the modern supermarkets, always adapting, always evolving...just like the Nile, it's a lifeline, a source of sustenance, a symbol of community and sharing...

And then there's the yeast, that tiny little creature that makes it all happen...a bit like the yeast of our own existence, rising to the occasion, fermenting our hopes and dreams, making us rise above the mundane...but also, like yeast, it can be a double-edged sword, consuming us, destroying us, leaving us flat and lifeless...

But, I digress...the history of bread is a long one, full of twists and turns, like a braid made of bread...it's been shaped and molded by countless hands, influenced by the cultures and civilizations that have risen and fallen...the ancient Greeks, the Romans, the Europeans, each leaving their mark on the bread, just as we leave our mark on the world...

And then, of course, there's the industrial revolution, the mechanization of bread-making...like the rise of the machines, the bread rose, but not in a good way...it lost its soul, its heart, its essence...became just another product, another commodity, another thing to be consumed and discarded...

But, as we all know, the best bread is still made by hand, by heart, by love...just like the old days, when bread was a labor of love, a gift to the community...now it's just a product, a commodity, a thing to be bought and sold...but
